label: TRAINING
data_answer: Tenochtitlan had three causeways that kept it connected to the land. They were made of stone and held up by wooden pillars that were made without iron or steel tools. There were also bridges made of wood which could be taken off to prevent enemies from getting in, as well as to let canoes get through. This shows that although the Aztecs didn't have metal tools, they managed to create a way to and from the mainland that could also protect them. They needed to be creative to do something like that. Source #2 and Source #3 The king of Tenochtitlan had a 10-mile dike built to keep a large source of fresh water in one place, untouched by salt water. The city's aqueducts brought water from there to the city. The acqueducts were stone with two clay pipes so that if one was being cleaned, the other would still bring water. This also shows that the Aztecs were clever enough to solve their problem of salty water and again do it without metal tools. They also had a steady source of fresh water for drinking and agriculture. Source #2 and Source #3

data_answer: Tenochtitlan was a very highly developed city, and these sources have a lot of information available that supports this. From "Technology in the Time of the Aztecs," by Nina Morgan, it mentions how they made special advanced tools with copper blades and obsidian tips. This supports the idea of the Aztecs being highly developed, because it is difficult to learn how to turn these materials into usable tools that are for their advantage. Also, in "The City of Tenochtitlan," by Robert Hull, it is mentioned that the city of Tenochtitlan was an unusually clean place, do to the fact that there were about a thousand men who swept and washed the streets every day. It takes a lot of responsibility and order to be able to have a system like that.

data_answer: Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city. In source #1, it states that the Aztecs depended more on human skill than machines. They used simple tools and built their temples and buildings.They had organized a water system so that everybody had clean water to drink. The Aztecs had built their cities on raised platforms to protect them from floods. The city was very organized and clean. In source #3, it talks about how the Aztecs had no money currency and only operated on trade. They put their most important buildings in the center of the city. The Aztecs used aqueducts to carry fresh spring water to the city. Later the water would be sold in the busy market streets. The markets had different sections like our markets today. Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city.

data_answer: There are many examples from different sources that support the idea that Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city. It also let them transport goods by boat and is an example of industry of a modern civilization. On Source #2 it says, "There were palaces, law courts, public baths, and markets. This shows many examples required for a modern civilization. There were law courts that were used for judging and was an example of government. It also says that there were markets that were used to sell goods and is a good example of industry. Today, we have markets too. There are many evidence in these sources that shows that Tenochtitlan was an advanced civilization.

data_answer: If I heard that the Aztec city, Tenochtitlan, was so highly developed, I would ask myself, how were they so highly developed? Tenochtitlan was highly developed in many ways. For example, in paragraph 9, the Aztecs in Tenochtitlan found out a way to trade without using money, and instead use items such as goose-quills filled with gold-dust. This led to amazingly busy and colorful markets in the city. The market created a place for the Aztecs to trade vegetables, clothes, and hardware which concluded in a huge development in Tenochtitlan. Also, in paragraph 4, it states the city was built around a network of canals. This made water transportation easy around the city. This means easier gardening, baths, and drinking water around the city. All in all, Tenochtitlan was a very highly developed city because they found a way to trade with items as currency and they made their city around a network of canals.

Another example of how Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city was because they used many advanced building tools. In the article, it states that they used hammers, axes, copper blades, chisels, and scrapers. In addition, the articles tells me that they used volcanic rock, obsidian, and pumice instead of regular rock to make their tools because these rocks are more harder and stronger, which is interesting because they were developed enough to come up with a better option for making better tools.

data_answer: In source #1 in the last paragraph, it states that the Aztecs were very successful using their skills."Although they had no iron tools or carts with wheels, and no alphabet, the Aztecs managed to build a highly developed civilization in just two hundred years." The Aztecs were able to make an advanced way of living without the use of iron tools, carts with wheels, or the alphabet. The success that lead to their great achievement was using simple tools with great skill. In source #3 in the last paragraph of the section of The City of Tenochtitlan, was the ability to use an aqueduct. "To keep the lake water around Tenochtitlan fresh, the Texcocoan king Nezahualcoyotl, built a 10 mile long dike." The unique part was that the dike was able to keep the lake water clean, and was able to seal off the western lagoon which was fed by the fresh spring water. The water came by aqueduct and was carried away to be sold in the streets.

data_answer: Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city. Also, in source #2, it says "Two stone aqueducts brought fresh water into Tenochtitlan from springs in the surrounding hills." This showed that this city was advanced because they figured out how to carry fresh water from one place to another without any manual labor.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Tenochtitlan, as stated in all sources of reading, was a highly developed city for its time. One example of this, stated in Source #1 (Technology in the Time of the Aztecs), indcates the advanced canal system in the city. The author states, "Tenochtitlan was linked to the mainland by three raised roads, or causeways. There were few streets in the city. Instead, the Aztecs built a regular grid of canals so that people could travel around the city and transport goods by boat." This example explains the Aztec's means of transportation. Now, if the reader analyzes this piece of information, they will have made an inference as to how efficient this was compared to other ways of transportation. This canal system, unlike other "roads" in a variety of cities, was more effiecient, faster, and even provided access to other parts of the town. Another piece of evidence that pertains towards the highly developed concept of the city can be found in Source #3 (The City of Tenochtitlan). In the text, the author states, "As the island city in the lake grew, food was needed for more and more people. Rocks and soil were brought by canoe from the mainland, to make more chinampas. On these chinampas, and on the fields around the lake, the Aztecs grew corn, beans, squash, chili peppers, tomatoes, and amaranth. People even built cane and thatch houses on their floating gardens." In this particular piece of evidence, the author highlights Tenochtitlan's experienced ways of agriculture. This further indicates that Tenochtitlan was an advanced city for it's time, seeing as though it is highly developed in a variety of areas (Agriculture, etc.). These exerpts from the text also support the fact that the citizens of Tenochtitlan are well organized and effcient.

data_answer: The City of Tenochtitlan- The palaces were two stories high and had 50 or more rooms. Montezuma's palace had its own parks and gardens with ponds where swana were kept. Many houses had flower gardens, small shaded courtyards and patios, and dikes full of water. A palace that would be known as a mansion today. Technology in the Time of the Aztecs- More than 250,000 people lived there when Cortes and his soldiers arrived. There were palaces and law courts, public baths and markets. Many houses were built on raised platforms to protect them from floods. Most were just one story high, because taller houses would have been too heavy to stand on marshy ground. Not many cities back then could accomplish that.

data_answer: Tenochtitlan was indeed a highly devoloped city. They had technology far beyond their time. In the text, it says, "Two stone aquaducts brought fresh water into Tenochtitlan from springs in the surrounding hills. hese had two clay pipes so that when one was being cleaned or repaired the other could carry water." (Source #2) This is crazy! Remember that this was a very, very, very, long time ago. These people didn't have tools like we do, or machines like ours, and yet, they still some how managed to create these wonderful things. Tey definitely had a high quality for living for that time period. Also in the text, "Tenochtitlan was linked to the main land by three raised roads or causeways." (Source #1) Again, they had only simple tools that they learned to use with great skill. This shows evidence of education or importance on learning which improves the standard of living and makes it a rather developed city. Plus, how on earth did tey build a causeway ith out tall machines and trucks? It truly was, an incredible city.

These examples showed me how truly developed and intelligent the Aztecs were for their time.

Chisels, hammers, and scrapers were often made of volcanic rock because this type of stone was very strong.

data_answer: In source #2, the Aztecs created aqueducts so they could bring in fresh water from water sources in the hills that surrounded the Aztec city. Also, in some places the aqueducts would open out to form reserviors to keep stock of the fresh water. label: TRAINING
data_answer: One example is under the heading, "Transporting Building Materials". The text reads, "The Aztecs had to carry all the stone and large pieces of wood they used in their buldings. Builders carried smaller materials in cone shaped baskets, called chundi, on their backs and supported the heavy load using a strap across their foreheads. We do not know how Aztecs moved blocks of stone or wood that were too heavy to carry. They did not have carts on wheels, so they must have found ways to use sleds, levers, and ropes, or rollers made from tree trunks to haul large blccks." This shows how Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city because, they did not have carts on wheels yet, so they figured out their own ways to carry heavy blocks to their working area. Another example is under the heading, "Markets and City Life". The text reads, "The city had amazingly busy and colorful markets. Each of the four main sections of the city had its local market." data_answer: One example that supports that Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city is from article #2. In this article it says, "Two stone aqueducts brought fresh water from springs in the surrounding hills. These had two clay pipes so that when one was being cleaned or repaired the other could carry water." This example shows that Tenochtitlan was highly developed because the Aztecs had aqeducts that could carry water into the city so people wouldn't have to fetch it themselves. Another example is from article #3. This article says,"Each of the four main sections of the city had its local market. There were also two huge ones, in Tenochtitlan and Tlaltelolco that offered virtually every product that the Aztec empire had to offer." This quote shows that Tenochtitlan is a highly developed city because there are many markets in the city that people get things from, and that they had lots of produts to trade for.

data_answer: Source #1. Tenochtitlan was an impressive city. It was far bigger than any European city of the time, and it was very well organized. Source #2. The Aztecs built three wide causeways to connect Tenochtitlan to the mainland. These were of stone, supported on wooden pillars.

data_answer: Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city. As source one mentions, "Tenochtitlan was an impressive city. Another example from source two says, "The Aztecs built three wide causeways to connect Tenochtitlan to the mainland. These were of stone, supported on wooden pillars. They built the causeways with gaps joined by wooden bridges that could be removed to allow canoes to pass through and to keep enemies out." This explains to you the brilliance of the Aztec architecture.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city well by source 1#. One of the details is that when the Spanish explorer Hernando Cortes led an army to Mexico in 1519 and met the Aztecs he was amazed by what he found. He saw cities and villages built of water and other great towns that were on dry land were out standing. Some of the towns were biult on dry land but others like the Aztec capital Tenochtitlan (now Mexico City) were biult on islands or on swampy marshland. Another one is that Tenochtitlan was linked to the mainland by three raised roads or causeways. There were few streets in the city. Instead the Aztecs built a regular grid of canals so the people could travel around the city. and transport goods by boat. On souce 2# an important detail is the Aztecs had good reason to br proud of there capital city when Cortes and his soldiers arived they were amazed to find that Tenochtitlan was far bigger than any European city. More than 250,000 people lived there there were law courts and public baths and markets. They had temples and the temples were the most important buildings in Aztec towns. They were built on top of pyramids usually on a plat form. Another one is that they had tool and there tools they used for crushing and hammering and they were made of wooden shafts and stone heads. There axes and other cuting tools had copper blades and chisels hammers and scrapers were often made of volcanoe rock because this type of stone was very hard and strong. For source 3# an important detail is thatThe city had many amazing busy and colorful markets each four mane sections of the city had its local market there were also two huge ones in Tenochtitlan and that offered virtually every product that the Aztec empire had to offer. The markets were near the center of Tenochtitlan but the city center itself was the temple precinct. It was dominated by the two great pyramids temples that stood side by side their flights of steps like a pair of escalators facing west. Near the tamples were the decorated stone palaces of the emporer and of the greatest nobles they were two stories high. Another one is that people grew gardens at there houses and they lived in tiny houses they grew flowers, peppers , squash, fruit and other stuff. All these examples support this idea because they are civilized in all these ways and all the examples say that they were a highly developed city they grew food and they built temples and had emporers and had nobles.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: I know Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city. I know this because in Source #2, it states that the Aztecs did not have any advanced transportation to transport blocks of stone or wood that were way to heavy to carry on their backs like smaller blocks, or else it would've crushed them. The Aztecs also did not have cart with wheels like a wheelbarrow, so they couldn't push the stones. Instead, this source thinks that the Aztecs must have found ways to use sleds, levers, ropes, or rollers made from tree trunks to haul the immense blocks. Whatever way they transported the heavy blocks needed imagination, so the Aztecs were really creative, which was a factor that determined that Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city. The second example in Source #1 states that even though only having simple tools to construct buildings, the Aztecs built magnificent temples with beautiful carvings to honor and worship the gods they believed in. They also honored the nobles and priests by building bigger and nicer houses than the ones ordinary people lived in, which were in the outskirts Tenochtitlan, far from the beautiful courtyard and temples. Despite only having simple tools to build their city, the Aztecs found a way to build extraordinary temples without using cranes and advanced tools like what we have today. Because of the evidence I found in the two sources I used to back up my statement, I still think that Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city and it was very advanced for the time period it existed in and found ways to solve many problems they faced.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city, or a civilization. A civilization is a group or society of people who have developed a form of culture, government, technology, and industry. All three sources give information that would help conclude that the Tenochtitlan is a well-developed civilization. For example, in source #2, the Aztec capital had a population of more than 250,000, and had public baths, markets, temples, villages, law courts, and palaces. Public baths and temples are examples of Aztec culture, markets can be examples of industries, and law courts were part of the Aztec government. A second example can be found in source #3, whrere, rather than roads, the city contained a large network of canals, used for trade and transport, and farms used to grow a variety of vegetables, grain, and flowers. This also supports this idea because canals and boats are an example of Aztec technology and farming is also an example of agriculture. Being one of the largest cities in the world, for its time, it is no doubt that Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city by 1519's standards.

data_answer: The most useful source that supports why Tenochtitlan is a highly developed city is Source #1. In the source, it says that the Aztec began to advance without an alphabet. The Aztecs also didn't have iron tools or carts to grow and expand their city while building. Its government has people sweeping and washing so that it remained that way. They also found a way to expell human waste from their city by using barges. Tenochtitlan was also an highly developed city because of the location where it wass built. label: VALIDATION
data_answer: You can see that Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city in these sources. In the source, "Technology in the Time of the Aztecs", the first paragraph says, "Although they had no iron tools or carts with wheels, and no alphabet, the Aztecs managed to build a highly developed civilization in just two hundred years." Clearly, the Aztecs were very skilled and only had to use simple tools to do this and it all worked out in the end. In the source, "Excerpt from Technology in the Time of the Aztecs", the section "Causeways, Bridges, and Aqueducts", states, "Two stone aqueducts brought fresh water into Tenochtitlan from springs in the surrounding hills." Obviously, having clean water in your city coming from aqueducts is pretty developed for a city back then. In every source there were examples about how developed the Aztec city was, and it even amazed the European explorers.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: "The Aztecs had good reason to be proud of their capitol city. When Cortes and his soldiers arrived, they were amazed to find that Tenochtitlan was far bigger than any European city." (Source #2, "Technology in the Time of the Aztecs"). This part of the text states that Cortes and his soldiers were in awe when they saw the city, and that the Aztecs had good reason to be proud of it. Cortes was from Spain, and he probably thought that Mesoamerica would be less developed than his country, but when he saw it, he was surprised to find that it was not any less developed than Spain. "Tenochtitlan was a typical city, with taverns, barber shops, and parks for relaxation." (Source #3, "The City of Tenochtitlan, 'Palaces'"). This part of the text describes the city in a way that we could describe our cities today. It lists many things that are very modern and highly developed that we still see in our own cities.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city. One example to support this idea, is that in the first source it says that Tenochtitlan was linked to the mainland by three raised roads and that the Aztecs had built a regular grid of canals so that people could travel around the city and transport goods by boat. Another example is that in the third source, it says that the temples were two stories high and that they had 50 rooms or more. The third source also says that the city had a local market for each section of the city. I think that these are good examples of how Tenochtitlan was a highly developed city.

data_answer: Technology in Aztec times depended more on human skills than on tools and machines. although they had no iron tools or carts with wheels, and no alphabet, the Aztecs managed to build a highly developed civilization in just two hundred years.The secret of their success was that they learned to use very simple tools with great skill.- Source one This example supports the idea because the Aztec was still a success even with little material Temples were among the most important building in Aztec towns. They were built on top of pyramids, usally on a platform made by leveling off the top of the pyramid. THe pyramid rose in terraces with a broad stairway leading to the temple at the top. Important temples had roofs made of wooden beams forming a point. These were coverd with sticks and twigs and coated with a plaster made of mud and animal dung to keep rain out. - Source two This example supports the idea because the Aztec were very creative about the platform and how thay made it.
